natural problem:
The matrix for reflecting through a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$
natural solution: If $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}$ is a vector in plane $P,$ then the reflection takes the vector to itself.

Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]Then

\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z = x,$ $\frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z = y,$ and $\frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z = z.$  Each of these equations reduces to
\[2x - y - 5z = 0,\]so the normal vector of the plane is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}}.$

a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for reflecting through a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 If $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}$ is a vector in plane $P,$ then the reflection takes the vector to itself.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z = x,$ $\frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z = y,$ and $\frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z = z.$  Each of these equations reduces to
 \[2x - y - 5z = 0,\]so the normal vector of the plane is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

lemma
fixes M :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "M = ((11 / 15, 2 / 15, 2 / 3), (2 / 15, 14 / 15, -1 / 3), (2 / 3, -1 / 3, -2 / 3))"
and h1 : "M *v v = - v"
shows  "v = vector [2, -1, -5]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a 3x3 matrix M with elements (11/15, 2/15, 2/3), (2/15, 14/15, -1/3), (2/3, -1/3, -2/3) and a vector v such that the matrix multiplication of M and v equals the negative of v. Find the vector v. The final answer is the vector [2, -1, -5].

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M :: "real^3^3" and n :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "M = (1/15) *\<^sub>R (vector [vector [11, 2, 10], vector [2, 14, -5], vector [10, -5, -10]])"
and h1 : "M *\<^sub>R n = - n"
shows  "n = vector [2, -1, -5]"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for reflecting through a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 If $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}$ is a vector in plane $P,$ then the reflection takes the vector to itself.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z = x,$ $\frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z = y,$ and $\frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z = z.$  Each of these equations reduces to
 \[2x - y - 5z = 0,\]so the normal vector of the plane is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes M :: "real^3^3" and n :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "M = (1/15) *\<^sub>R (vector [vector [11, 2, 10], vector [2, 14, -5], vector [10, -5, -10]])"
and h1 : "M *\<^sub>R n = - n"
shows  "n = vector [2, -1, -5]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a matrix $M = \frac{1}{15} \begin{bmatrix} 11 & 2 & 10 \\ 2 & 14 & -5 \\ 10 & -5 & -10 \end{bmatrix}$ and a vector $n$ such that $Mn = -n$, find the vector $n$. The final answer is $n = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{bmatrix}$.

a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for reflecting through a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 If $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}$ is a vector in plane $P,$ then the reflection takes the vector to itself.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z = x,$ $\frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z = y,$ and $\frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z = z.$  Each of these equations reduces to
 \[2x - y - 5z = 0,\]so the normal vector of the plane is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "P = matrix([[11/15, 2/15, 2/3], [2/15, 14/15, -1/3], [2/3, -1/3, -2/3]])"
and h1 : "v = matrix([2, -1, -5])"
and h2 : "P *v v = -v"
shows  "v = matrix([2, -1, -5])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a 3x3 matrix P with elements [[11/15, 2/15, 2/3], [2/15, 14/15, -1/3], [2/3, -1/3, -2/3]] and a 3x1 vector v with elements [2, -1, -5], find the vector v such that when P is multiplied by v, the result is negative v. The solution is [2, -1, -5].

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "P = matrix([[11/15, 2/15, 2/3], [2/15, 14/15, -1/3], [2/3, -1/3, -2/3]])"
and h1 : "v = vector[2, -1, -5]"
shows  "matrix.reflect P v = v"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for reflecting through a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 If $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}$ is a vector in plane $P,$ then the reflection takes the vector to itself.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z = x,$ $\frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z = y,$ and $\frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z = z.$  Each of these equations reduces to
 \[2x - y - 5z = 0,\]so the normal vector of the plane is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "P = matrix([[11/15, 2/15, 2/3], [2/15, 14/15, -1/3], [2/3, -1/3, -2/3]])"
and h1 : "v = vector[2, -1, -5]"
shows  "matrix.reflect P v = v"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given a matrix $P = \begin{bmatrix} 11/15 & 2/15 & 2/3 \\ 2/15 & 14/15 & -1/3 \\ 2/3 & -1/3 & -2/3 \end{bmatrix}$ and a vector $v = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{bmatrix}$, show that the reflection of the vector $v$ in the plane represented by matrix $P$ is the vector $v$ itself.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "M = matrix([[11/15, 2/15, 2/3], [2/15, 14/15, -1/3], [2/3, -1/3, -2/3]])"
and h1 : "v \<bullet> (M *v v) = 0"
shows  "v = vector[2, -1, -5]"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for reflecting through a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 If $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}$ is a vector in plane $P,$ then the reflection takes the vector to itself.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z = x,$ $\frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z = y,$ and $\frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z = z.$  Each of these equations reduces to
 \[2x - y - 5z = 0,\]so the normal vector of the plane is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes M :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "M = matrix([[11/15, 2/15, 2/3], [2/15, 14/15, -1/3], [2/3, -1/3, -2/3]])"
and h1 : "v \<bullet> (M *v v) = 0"
shows  "v = vector[2, -1, -5]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the vector $v$ in three-dimensional space such that the dot product of $v$ and the result of multiplying matrix $M$ by $v$ equals zero, where $M$ is the matrix $\begin{bmatrix} 11/15 & 2/15 & 2/3 \\ 2/15 & 14/15 & -1/3 \\ 2/3 & -1/3 & -2/3 \end{bmatrix}$. The vector $v$ is $\begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{bmatrix}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[11/15, 2/15, 2/3], [2/15, 14/15, -1/3], [2/3, -1/3, -2/3]])"
and h1 : "v = vector[2, -1, -5]"
shows  "A \<bullet> v = 0"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for reflecting through a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 If $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}$ is a vector in plane $P,$ then the reflection takes the vector to itself.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z = x,$ $\frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z = y,$ and $\frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z = z.$  Each of these equations reduces to
 \[2x - y - 5z = 0,\]so the normal vector of the plane is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[11/15, 2/15, 2/3], [2/15, 14/15, -1/3], [2/3, -1/3, -2/3]])"
and h1 : "v = vector[2, -1, -5]"
shows  "A \<bullet> v = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find if the vector [2, -1, -5] is orthogonal to the matrix [[11/15, 2/15, 2/3], [2/15, 14/15, -1/3], [2/3, -1/3, -2/3]]. The final answer is true.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "P = matrix([[11/15, 2/15, 2/3], [2/15, 14/15, -1/3], [2/3, -1/3, -2/3]])"
and h1 : "det P = 1"
shows  "normal_vector P = vector [2, -1, -5]"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for reflecting through a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 If $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}$ is a vector in plane $P,$ then the reflection takes the vector to itself.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z = x,$ $\frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z = y,$ and $\frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z = z.$  Each of these equations reduces to
 \[2x - y - 5z = 0,\]so the normal vector of the plane is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "P = matrix([[11/15, 2/15, 2/3], [2/15, 14/15, -1/3], [2/3, -1/3, -2/3]])"
and h1 : "det P = 1"
shows  "normal_vector P = vector [2, -1, -5]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a 3x3 matrix P with entries P = $\begin{bmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{bmatrix}$ and a determinant of 1, find its normal vector. The final answer is the vector [2, -1, -5].

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Matrix :: "real^3^3" and Vector :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "Matrix = (1/15) * (vector [11,2,10] , vector [2,14,-5] , vector [10,-5,-10])"
shows  "Vector = vector [2,-1,-5]"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for reflecting through a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 If $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}$ is a vector in plane $P,$ then the reflection takes the vector to itself.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z = x,$ $\frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z = y,$ and $\frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z = z.$  Each of these equations reduces to
 \[2x - y - 5z = 0,\]so the normal vector of the plane is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes Matrix :: "real^3^3" and Vector :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "Matrix = (1/15) * (vector [11,2,10] , vector [2,14,-5] , vector [10,-5,-10])"
shows  "Vector = vector [2,-1,-5]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a 3x3 matrix with the rows being the vectors [11,2,10], [2,14,-5], and [10,-5,-10] scaled by 1/15, find a 3-dimensional vector. The final answer is the vector [2,-1,-5].

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[11/15, 2/15, 2/3], [2/15, 14/15, -1/3], [2/3, -1/3, -2/3]])"
and h1 : "v = vector [2,-1,-5]"
shows  "normal_vector_of_plane A = v"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for reflecting through a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 If $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}$ is a vector in plane $P,$ then the reflection takes the vector to itself.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z = x,$ $\frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z = y,$ and $\frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z = z.$  Each of these equations reduces to
 \[2x - y - 5z = 0,\]so the normal vector of the plane is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[11/15, 2/15, 2/3], [2/15, 14/15, -1/3], [2/3, -1/3, -2/3]])"
and h1 : "v = vector [2,-1,-5]"
shows  "normal_vector_of_plane A = v"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the normal vector of a plane with a given matrix representation $A$ where $A$ is a $3 \times 3$ matrix with entries $A = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{array} \right]$. The final answer is the vector $v = [2, -1, -5]$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes matrix :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "matrix = (1/15) *\<^sub>R (vector [11, 2, 20]) outer vector [11, 2, 20] - (2/15) *\<^sub>R (vector [11, 2, 20]) outer vector [2, 14, -5] + (2/3) *\<^sub>R (vector [11, 2, 20]) outer vector [20, -5, -10] + 
                        (2/15) *\<^sub>R (vector [2, 14, -5]) outer vector [11, 2, 20] - (14/15) *\<^sub>R (vector [2, 14, -5]) outer vector [2, 14, -5] - (1/3) *\<^sub>R (vector [2, 14, -5]) outer vector [20, -5, -10] + 
                        (2/3) *\<^sub>R (vector [20, -5, -10]) outer vector [11, 2, 20] - (1/3) *\<^sub>R (vector [20, -5, -10]) outer vector [2, 14, -5] - (2/3) *\<^sub>R (vector [20, -5, -10]) outer vector [20, -5, -10]"
shows  "normal_vector = vector [2, -1, -5]"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for reflecting through a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 If $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}$ is a vector in plane $P,$ then the reflection takes the vector to itself.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} & \frac{2}{15} & \frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{2}{15} & \frac{14}{15} & -\frac{1}{3} \\ \frac{2}{3} & -\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{2}{3} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
 \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z \\ \frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\frac{11}{15} x + \frac{2}{15} y + \frac{2}{3} z = x,$ $\frac{2}{15} x + \frac{14}{15} y - \frac{1}{3} z = y,$ and $\frac{2}{3} x - \frac{1}{3} y - \frac{2}{3} z = z.$  Each of these equations reduces to
 \[2x - y - 5z = 0,\]so the normal vector of the plane is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes matrix :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "matrix = (1/15) *\<^sub>R (vector [11, 2, 20]) outer vector [11, 2, 20] - (2/15) *\<^sub>R (vector [11, 2, 20]) outer vector [2, 14, -5] + (2/3) *\<^sub>R (vector [11, 2, 20]) outer vector [20, -5, -10] + 
                        (2/15) *\<^sub>R (vector [2, 14, -5]) outer vector [11, 2, 20] - (14/15) *\<^sub>R (vector [2, 14, -5]) outer vector [2, 14, -5] - (1/3) *\<^sub>R (vector [2, 14, -5]) outer vector [20, -5, -10] + 
                        (2/3) *\<^sub>R (vector [20, -5, -10]) outer vector [11, 2, 20] - (1/3) *\<^sub>R (vector [20, -5, -10]) outer vector [2, 14, -5] - (2/3) *\<^sub>R (vector [20, -5, -10]) outer vector [20, -5, -10]"
shows  "normal_vector = vector [2, -1, -5]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
